p: Recently, using the natural material has become ideal for treatment of microbial infections due to the possible toxic or harmful effects of many chemical antimicrobial agents [ 33]. Figure 4 shows the antimicrobial mechanisms of chemical antimicrobial agents against herbal antimicrobial agents [ 34, 35]. The application of herbal materials would be an ideal alternative [ 36, 37] and can also open up a new chance for producing new anticancer, antimicrobial, and antiviral drugs with lower side effects. There is much research that has demonstrated this material as a potential antimicrobial agent. This review paper is concerned with the pharmacological effects and properties of several herbal plants including clove, portulaca, tribulus, eryngium, cinnamon, turmeric, ginger, thyme, pennyroyal, mint, fennel, chamomile, burdock, eucalyptus, primrose, lemon balm, mallows, and garlic with good potential for antimicrobial, antiviral, and radical scavenger abilities.
